title: Fuji hogs the horizon as ITV fails to park stereotypes but passes World Cup test | Simon Burnton
text:
Close your eyes and design, in the realm of your imagination, a Japan-themed TV studio. Come back whenever you’re ready. Of course you’re probably not a professional studio designer, and you almost certainly won’t spend more than a few seconds on the task, so you might have accepted a few lazy cliches and tired stereotypes. I’m wagering there was a lot of cherry blossom involved, a bonsai tree or two, perhaps some paper lanterns and a view of Mount Fuji. Well that image in your head is the ITV World Cup studio. They gave the Great Wave a wide berth and shirked the sushi, but otherwise it’s all there.

Japan open Rugby World Cup by overcoming dogged Russia Read more

But if ITV has played safe with the studio, its choice of theme music has come way out of left field. Unlike, say, in 2007, when it simply used the tournament’s official anthem (a version of World in Union by a supergroup featuring Katherine Jenkins, Bryn Terfel, Lesley Garrett and others) or in 2011, when they used the tournament’s official anthem (a version of World in Union by Hayley Westenra) or for that matter in 2015, when they used the tournament’s official anthem (a version of World in Union by Paloma Faith), this time they shunned the tournament’s official anthem (a version of World in Union by Kiyoe Yoshioka) in favour of their own specially-commissioned accompaniment (a version of World in Union by Emeli Sandé). This is revolutionary, in its way.

Another surprise follows halfway through the opening programme, when presenter Mark Pougatch reveals a hitherto hidden annexe to the main studio. This dojo is, he explains, “our demonstration area, where we’re going to be illustrating some of the important points of the game, especially for those of you who aren’t regular rugby-watchers”. Jonny Wilkinson, Sam Warburton and Brian O’Driscoll proceed to put on an extremely complicated exposition on the art of tackling and the rules that govern it. “It’s all about understanding what a wrap actually entails,” concludes O’Driscoll. “You must wrap with your tackling shoulder.” Those who aren’t regular rugby-watchers, and for whom a wrap more commonly entails a visit to the sandwich aisle in Tesco, are unlikely to be significantly wiser.

The opening ceremony is not a classic of the genre. Since the invention of miraculous enormous pitch-covering floor-screens it has become too easy to avoid the complex retellings of the history of sport through the medium of folk dancing which were once a staple of such occasions in favour of simply showing some video, which is diverting enough but not really in the spirit. Still, commentator Miles Harrison gets to deliver a few classic lines – “A rugby ball becomes a seed of light spreading around the world” – so our time was not totally wasted.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest The art of tackling was demonstrated in a hidden annexe to the main studio modelled on a dojo. Photograph: ITV Sport

The ceremony concludes when an area of miracle floor-screen, having already transformed into Mount Fuji, splits open to reveal Richie McCaw waving the Webb Ellis Cup. A few minutes later ITV returns to the stadium for a chat with the former Wales international Shane Williams. “You can hear behind us now,” he says, gesturing to the crowd, “the rugby hasn’t even kicked off, the opening ceremony hasn’t kicked off, and they’re already having a party.” It may have been expedient to pre-record this segment, and convenient not to mention they had done so, but they could at least have used some of the time that bought them to insist Williams find something less confusing to say.

Williams is exposed again with the game barely five minutes old, as he describes Will Tupou completely failing to catch the ball and thus allowing Russia to snaffle an early try. “I’m not sure who’s under this,” he expert-analyses, “but he gets nowhere near it, does he?” That slight mis-step apart, the game – unlike Tupou’s catch – is largely well handled. The hosts run out easy and popular victors, and attention instantly turns to Saturday and the mouth-watering meeting of South Africa and New Zealand.

In ITV’s closing moments Bryan Habana, the former Springbok wing, is asked for his thoughts on that game. “Let’s just make sure we get the traffic in early because there might be quite a few cars going to that stadium,” he says. That is literally all Habana has to say on perhaps the tie of the pool stage. And so ends ITV’s first test of the tournament, a few hours with no car crashes but perhaps just the occasional snarl-up.
description: Japanese cliches, popular victors and a confusing tackle ‘demonstration area’ made for interesting viewing on the opening day
